abstract: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week — from the White House  to new technologies to Zig Ziglar.
snippet: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week — from the White House  to new technologies to Zig Ziglar.
lead_paragraph: MANY SMALL BIZ OWNERS HOPING FOR A CHANGE TOMORROW? As the election looms, President Obama continues to talk about how his administration is helping small business. But a survey issued last week said that most small-business owners are voting Republican. Another poll finds that “nearly 80 percent of the business community believes that business interests would best be served if the Democratic Party lost majority control of either the House or the Senate.” David Leonhardt of The New York Times says job losses overshadowed the president’s accomplishments. The president pleads for patience with Jon Stewart and promises to start focusing on the deficit next term. Blogger Justin Fox explains the deficit. A new graphic shows how Americans feel about the recession. The national debt is projected to reach three times the size of the economy in 2050 and Reuters columnist James Pethokoukis doesn’t think the President’s deficit panel is on track.

headline.main: This Week in Small Business: Is the Horror Over?

abstract: The Deal Professor examines how there is a lack of empirical evidence about the actual effect that proxy access would have on the value of public corporations.
snippet: The Deal Professor examines how there is a lack of empirical evidence about the actual effect that proxy access would have on the value of public corporations.
lead_paragraph: Proxy access is a hotly debated topic. Advocates contend that loosening the limits on proxy access will empower shareholders, heighten board accountability, restore shareholder confidence and result in more economically run public corporations. Detractors refute these propositions and assert that proxy access is a Potemkin village that will pre-empt state law, enable special-interest shareholders to hold up companies and otherwise provide corporations with few of the benefits that its proponents argue, other than increased costs to comply with new regulations.

headline.main: The Heated Debate Over Proxy Access

abstract: An obscure amendment to the Dodd-Frank legislation repeals a law that prohibited financial institutions from paying interest on business checking accounts. Who knew?
snippet: An obscure amendment to the Dodd-Frank legislation repeals a law that prohibited financial institutions from paying interest on business checking accounts. Who knew?
lead_paragraph: A little-known amendment to the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act could reshape the way small businesses bank. The amendment, added in the House of Representatives with no debate, repeals a law that prohibited financial institutions from paying interest on business checking accounts, which are known as demand deposit accounts. The prohibition had been part of the Glass-Steagall Act and was in force for nearly 70 years.

headline.main: Interest Checking for Small Businesses?

abstract: Many have gone a long time without a raise. It is not an easy situation.
snippet: Many have gone a long time without a raise. It is not an easy situation.
lead_paragraph: It has now been almost three years since the economy entered the Great Recession and two years since it took the nosedive in the fall of 2008. Though the economists say the recession was over months ago, the small-business owners I talk to have not seen sales rebound to where they were. Some businesses haven’t rebounded at all. I have been in business for more than 30 years, and I have never seen anything like this. It’s like a normal recession but with an extra year or two thrown in. Yes, things have stabilized, and in some cases they have gotten better. On the human side, things are precarious.

headline.main: Do Employees Still Feel Lucky to Have Jobs?

abstract: While talking about money with children has long been taboo, avoiding the conversation can have unintended and unhappy consequences.
snippet: While talking about money with children has long been taboo, avoiding the conversation can have unintended and unhappy consequences.
lead_paragraph: LOVE, Erich Segal wrote in 1970, means never having to say you’re sorry. The same can be said about the money amassed by the baby-boomer generation in the last four decades, or about their heirs’ view of it. Many parents remain reluctant to talk about how much money they plan to leave their children, and that can lead to conflict among siblings and hurt feelings long after the parents are gone.

lead_paragraph: LAST spring, Jamie McGurk, an independent producer in Los Angeles, knew that the rough economic climate would make it difficult for her 22-year-old daughter Stephanie to get a job. So when Stephanie decided to move back home after graduating from Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., her mother was delighted. “We didn’t get to spend that much time with her when she was on the East Coast, so it was the best thing ever,” she said.

abstract: The blogosphere is abuzz this afternoon with a story about Monica Gaudio, a writer who found an article she wrote in 2005 about the evolution of English apple pie recipes in a food magazine called Cooks Source. The issue? Ms. Gaudio said she had never been contacted by the publication about using her article.
snippet: The blogosphere is abuzz this afternoon with a story about Monica Gaudio, a writer who found an article she wrote in 2005 about the evolution of English apple pie recipes in a food magazine called Cooks Source. The issue? Ms. Gaudio said she had n...
lead_paragraph: The blogosphere is abuzz this afternoon with a story about Monica Gaudio, a writer who found an article she wrote in 2005 about the evolution of English apple pie recipes in a food magazine called Cooks Source. The issue? Ms. Gaudio said she had never been contacted by the publication about using her article.  Thanks to the Internet, the debate has been playing out on the likes of  Twitter and Facebook and the author’s own LiveJournal page, where Ms. Gaudio wrote about how she tried contacting the publication after a friend told her he had seen her article in it. According to the post, Ms. Gaudio contacted Judith Griggs, the magazine’s editor, and asked for the following:

abstract: The Washington Post Company said third-quarter profit more than tripled on sales growth in its Kaplan unit, which is facing government scrutiny, and a pickup in advertising revenue in its newspaper business.
snippet: The Washington Post Company said third-quarter profit more than tripled on sales growth in its Kaplan unit, which is facing government scrutiny, and a pickup in advertising revenue in its newspaper business.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Post Company said third-quarter profit more than tripled on sales growth in its higher education unit, which is facing government scrutiny, and a pickup in advertising revenue in its newspaper business. The company, which publishes The Washington Post, said it earned $60.9 million, or $6.84 a share, up from $17.1 million, or $1.81 a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 7.3 percent, to $1.19 billion. Earnings doubled at the Kaplan education unit, which accounts for almost two-thirds of revenue. Still, enrollment growth for higher education programs slowed, and the company said that pending government regulation of commercial colleges and a new free-trial period for students might hurt earnings. Revenue at the newspaper division rose 5 percent to $163.4 million. The Post’s print ad sales rose 3 percent to $72 million. Stock in the Post Company, which is based in Washington, rose $14.48, or 3.8 percent, to $398.38.

headline.main: Education Unit Lifts Washington Post Company
headline.print_headline: Education Unit Lifts Washington Post Company

abstract: Shares in the Fluor Corporation surged nearly 10 percent in response to the announcement that the company’s order backlog had expanded 18 percent and that it would increase its share buybacks.
snippet: Shares in the Fluor Corporation surged nearly 10 percent in response to the announcement that the company’s order backlog had expanded 18 percent and that it would increase its share buybacks.
lead_paragraph: Shares in the Fluor Corporation, the construction company, surged nearly 10 percent in response to the company’s announcement that its order backlog had expanded 18 percent and that it would increase its share buybacks. On Thursday, Fluor raised its share repurchase program by 7.2 million shares to a total of 12 million shares, or 6.7 percent of its outstanding stock as of Oct. 29. The company said its order backlog rose to $33 billion in the third quarter amid new project awards for infrastructure, mining, oil and gas, including an oil sands project in Canada. The increase marked the second consecutive quarter of expansion, Fluor said. Stock in Fluor, which is based in Irving, Tex., rose $4.73, to $54.53.

headline.main: Fluor’s Shares Surge on Improved Business Outlook
headline.print_headline: Fluor’s Shares Surge On Improved Business Outlook

abstract: Ireland round-up; Goldman defends Bernanke; Estate-tax smackdowns.
snippet: Ireland round-up; Goldman defends Bernanke; Estate-tax smackdowns.
lead_paragraph: –A page one story by Landon Thomas Jr. on Monday looks at Irish debt, and what it portends for Europe. John Bruton, former prime minister of that embattled nation, assures us via Bloomberg that a default is unthinkable — short-sellers, beware. The ever astute Morgan Kelly, however, warns that while bad loans to developers have caused great grief so far, greater grief awaits the Irish when their long recession finally causes a wave of mortgage defaults. And finally, looking back to 2006, what do you want to bet that Malcolm Gladwell wants to revise this analysis. Toward the end of the Irish expansion, growth was built on cheap debt, a real estate bubble and a smattering of fraud.

headline.main: Morning Take-Out

Recently he went through rehabilitation, NBC reported in a segment this month.

abstract: These are heady, unpredictable days in the corner offices of Manhattan media, and what historically was a rather stately progression built on hierarchy and tradition has turned into a game of musical chairs with a very unpredictable soundtrack.

snippet: For my last post, I decided to call up a skeptic and ask why he hadn’t tried open-book management.
lead_paragraph: I think it’s fair to say that most business owners think that open-book management makes sense for their business — at least at some level. Sure, there will always be skeptics, but it’s tough to argue with the 30 years of results that we’ve seen at SRC. At the risk of repeating myself, I believe that by opening the books and empowering everyone in our organization to have a say in how we approach the future, we have found a way to deal with the risk of operating a business and also share the rewards that come with success.

headline.main: So Why Aren’t You Opening Your Books, Jay?

abstract: No one likes the measure. The dispute is about replacing lost revenue.

lead_paragraph: When we last checked in on efforts in Congress to roll back the expansion of 1099 reporting that passed as part of the health care overhaul, we found the parties deadlocked. Not on whether the new provision should be eliminated — both agreed that it should (at least in the House; in the Senate, Democrats proposed softening it rather than eliminating it). The argument, rather, was over how to pay for eliminating it. Now, in the wake of a disastrous midterm election, Democrats seem ready to avoid that fight by not paying for the repeal at all. But it is unclear that Republicans will go along.

Gordon on Dec. 15. According to one person who was briefed on the closed-door proceedings, and who spoke on condition of anonymity because of their sensitivity, Ms. Grigorieva testified but Mr. Gibson did not. Several readers commented that La Grande Dame’s Web site contributed to its S.E.O. challenges and urged an overhaul to address that issue and improve the site’s appearance and functionality. abstract: Apax Partners has agreed to acquire Advantage Sales and Marketing from J. W. Childs Associates and BAML Capital Partners.
snippet: Apax Partners has agreed to acquire Advantage Sales and Marketing from J. W. Childs Associates and BAML Capital Partners.
lead_paragraph: Apax Partners has agreed to acquire Advantage Sales and Marketing from J. W. Childs Associates and BAML Capital Partners, the latest large leveraged buyout in which a company would pass from one private equity group to another. The deal values Advantage at about $1.8 billion, according to a person close to the deal who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss it publicly. Apax will acquire about 85 percent of the company, with Advantage’s existing management owning the rest. Advantage, based in Irvine, Calif., is a leading sales and marketing agency for consumer goods, working with clients like J. M. Smucker and Johnson & Johnson to maximize the value of their brands. The company has about $1 billion in annual revenue and is expected to generate about $180 million in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization this year, according to this person. J. W. Childs and BAML Capital Partners, formerly Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity, acquired the closely held Advantage in 2006 for $1.05 billion. The firms are expected to make roughly three times their cash investment on the deal, which is expected to close by year-end.

headline.main: Agency Sold by One Private Equity Firm to Another

abstract: Italian rules allowing candy makers including Nestlé to label their products as “pure chocolate” breach European Union law, the bloc’s highest court in Luxembourg said.
snippet: Italian rules allowing candy makers including Nestlé to label their products as “pure chocolate” breach European Union law, the bloc’s highest court in Luxembourg said.
lead_paragraph: Italian rules allowing candy makers including Nestlé to label their products as “pure chocolate” breach European Union law, the bloc’s highest court in Luxembourg said. The law “makes no provision for the sales name ‘pure chocolate,’ ” the court said. Allowing an extra sales name for chocolate that contains no vegetable fat “is likely to mislead consumers and thus interfere with their right to obtain correct, neutral and objective information.” Chocolate rules have led to legal battles since 1973, when Britain, Ireland and Denmark joined the European Union in resisting standards that required chocolate to contain only cocoa fats. Under the old rules, countries like Italy were allowed to block imports of chocolate made with alternative fats.

headline.main: Court Rules Against Candy Labeled ‘Pure Chocolate’

snippet: Kits about HIV and AIDS will be provided to 500,000 hair stylists and salons that are served by the L’Oréal professional products division as part of a campaign called Hairdressers Against AIDS on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Remember the old slogan for Clairol hair coloring, “Only her hairdresser knows for sure”? A campaign to help fight AIDS, which is to get under way on Tuesday, is based on the idea of hairdressers imparting to customers their knowledge of preventing the spread of H.I.V., which causes AIDS.

headline.main: Pass the Hairspray, Fight AIDS

abstract: While some European countries are struggling with debt, many of their companies are in great shape.
snippet: While some European countries are struggling with debt, many of their companies are in great shape.
lead_paragraph: The news that the Swiss group ABB is buying the Baldor Electric Company, an American motor maker,  points to a paradox in Europe that could bode well for mergers and acquisitions on the Continent next year.

headline.main: Despite ABB Deal, Europe Is Cautious on Mergers

abstract: The concerns in the bond markets are further straining the decade-old monetary union.
snippet: The concerns in the bond markets are further straining the decade-old monetary union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fears over the European financial crisis began to spread Tuesday from the weaker countries to healthier ones, including Italy and Belgium, and even much stronger Germany, spurring a stepped up search for a solution to the economic problems putting a strain on Europe’s decade-old monetary union.

headline.main: Europe Examines Ways to Quell Its Debt Crisis
headline.print_headline: ANXIOUS EUROPE EXAMINING WAYS TO QUELL A CRISIS

abstract: The end of a federal grant program on Dec. 31 has spurred a race by companies to build solar energy systems.
snippet: The end of a federal grant program on Dec. 31 has spurred a race by companies to build solar energy systems.
lead_paragraph: Owners of commercial buildings are rushing in such numbers to meet an end-of-the-year deadline for a federal Treasury grant program for solar energy installations that inventories of some equipment have dried up, solar energy experts said.

headline.main: A Solar Installation Spree as the Deadline for Federal Grants Approaches
headline.print_headline: A Solar Installation Spree as the Deadline for Federal Grants Approaches

abstract: The Federal Communications Commission is looking into claims that Comcast has unfairly erected a tollbooth that threatens the transmission of online videos.
snippet: The Federal Communications Commission is looking into claims that Comcast has unfairly erected a tollbooth that threatens the transmission of online videos.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said Tuesday that the agency was looking into claims by Level 3 Communications that Comcast had unfairly erected a toll booth that “threatens the open Internet.”

headline.main: F.C.C. Investigates Complaint Against Comcast
